channel.title: Apache Web Server help
channel.description: Hey, I just stopped using IIS 7 because I heard it sucks badly and that Apache is much better. I've got Apache installed and all, and the localhost works. But when I go to my public IP address, it takes me to my router page, and not the Apache default page. I've tried having my friends go to my IP address and they say it doesn't work, along with http://192.168.1.102 Is it because I use wireless internet or something? My internet port is 80. I'm really confused with all of this. And my parent's computer's IP address is the same as mine, so that adds on some extra frustration in this. What do I do?

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

K, I extracted lighthttpd to C:\lighthttpd, but I don’t know what to click to run it.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

GZip? WinRar works. Heres some more info:
http://www.gzip.org/

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

Anybody know which program I use to open a tar.gz file? I use WinZIP and I’ve never been familiar with which program to use to open tar.gz or .gz archives

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

http://www.joomlaperformance.com/articles/benchmarks/lighttpd_vs._apache_joomla_1.5.1_39_15_5.html

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:34, topic:330494”]Well it looks like httpd.exe is using the correct port… perhaps you accidently ran two of them.

Everything looks in order I think your good to go.[/quote]
Probably.
Thanks guy!
If I could rep++ you, I would, but you both are at 200 rep already so, sorry.
I’ll restart my computer and see if that’ll help with the 0.0.0.0:80 problem. I’m just glad the others can visit the website.
Thanks again! =]

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:35, topic:330494”]Just download wamp if you can’t configure apache.

But really, you should not use apache at all, use lighthttpd because it is over 9000 times better.

and ps, ofc 192.168.1.102 will go to your router because that’s your defualt gateway. Just use http://localhost and it will be fine.[/quote]
Thanks Fat Cookies. I’ll fumble around with lighthttpd and see if I’ll stick with that.

[quote=“Davidi2, post:37, topic:330494”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=426871.msg3135065#msg3135065 date=1266875795]
But really, you should not use apache at all, use lighthttpd because it is over 9000 times better.
[/quote]
Technically it’s 94% better. (Want a link, I can provide the test results)[/quote]
lol Thanks for the statistics David

Read full topic

But really, you should not use apache at all, use lighthttpd because it is over 9000 times better.

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Just download wamp if you can’t configure apache.

But really, you should not use apache at all, use lighthttpd because it is over 9000 times better.

and ps, ofc 192.168.1.102 will go to your router because that’s your defualt gateway. Just use http://localhost and it will be fine.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Well it looks like httpd.exe is using the correct port… perhaps you accidently ran two of them.

Everything looks in order I think your good to go.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:31, topic:330494”]I doubt any of those programs would mess with it…

And:

I did a little editing regarding the DNS IP thing:

# ServerName gives the name and port that the server uses to identify itself.
# This can often be determined automatically, but we recommend you specify
# it explicitly to prevent problems during startup.
#
# If your host doesn't have a registered DNS name, enter its IP address here.
#
ServerName worldwidetechies.zapto.org:80

I had my friends test it out again and it showed a page to them saying “It works!”. So the website is up and fully working. It’s just that CMD window that I’m having troubles with now.

No do my command prompt thing :P.

Apart from this time cd to your Apache2/bin directory and then run httpd.exe…

Got this:

(OS 10048)Only one usage of each socket address (protocol/network address/port)
is normally permitted.  : make_sock: could not bind to address 0.0.0.0:80
no listening sockets available, shutting down
Unable to open logs

I thought you said that it works? Why change it if it works.[/quote]
I’m a perfectionist that wants everything working including the CMD window.

Ollie123, here’s what I found

ollie123:

Limewire does use port 80, try stopping that.

I checked Limewire, it was using a port in the thousands

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

Limewire does use port 80, try stopping that.

Read full topic

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I doubt any of those programs would mess with it…

And:

[quote=“r0ckstar96, post:22, topic:330494”]I did a little editing regarding the DNS IP thing:

# ServerName gives the name and port that the server uses to identify itself.
# This can often be determined automatically, but we recommend you specify
# it explicitly to prevent problems during startup.
#
# If your host doesn't have a registered DNS name, enter its IP address here.
#
ServerName worldwidetechies.zapto.org:80

I had my friends test it out again and it showed a page to them saying “It works!”. So the website is up and fully working. It’s just that CMD window that I’m having troubles with now.

No do my command prompt thing :P.

Apart from this time cd to your Apache2/bin directory and then run httpd.exe…

Got this:

(OS 10048)Only one usage of each socket address (protocol/network address/port) is normally permitted. : make_sock: could not bind to address 0.0.0.0:80 no listening sockets available, shutting down Unable to open logs [/quote]
I thought you said that it works? Why change it if it works.

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

Uh ohh. There were so many IP addresses that it couldn’t display the ones at the top of the list

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

It will usually be at the top of the list.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

[quote=“ollie123, post:27, topic:330494”]Could be any one of those programs.

Start Command Prompt as an administrator (if you are on Vista or 7). Type in “netstat -a -b”. A list will be displayed. Find the one with the IP address followed by :80, and above that should be the name of the program using that port.[/quote]
Great balls of zeus that’s a lot of IP addresses!
I’ll get back to you ASAP once I find the program causing this problem

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

Could be any one of those programs.

Start Command Prompt as an administrator (if you are on Vista or 7). Type in “netstat -a -b”. A list will be displayed. Find the one with the IP address followed by :80, and above that should be the name of the program using that port.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

I’m still getting the same problem even though I disabled IIS 7 and uninstalled Skype (I never really used it so there was no point in keeping it)
Could it be a program like Steam, Yahoo Messenger, Windows Live, FreeVPN, Trend Micro, LimeWire, or uTorrent?

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

That’s your problem, Apache cannot start because another program is using port 80.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

ollie123:

Aha, that means some other program is running on port 80. Have you got Skype by any chance, that could be causing the problem.

Yup. I’m going to disable IIS 7. I think I might still have it started somewhere. >.>

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

Aha, that means some other program is running on port 80. Have you got Skype by any chance, that could be causing the problem.

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

I did a little editing regarding the DNS IP thing:

# ServerName gives the name and port that the server uses to identify itself.
# This can often be determined automatically, but we recommend you specify
# it explicitly to prevent problems during startup.
#
# If your host doesn't have a registered DNS name, enter its IP address here.
#
ServerName worldwidetechies.zapto.org:80

I had my friends test it out again and it showed a page to them saying “It works!”. So the website is up and fully working. It’s just that CMD window that I’m having troubles with now.

[quote=“ollie123, post:21, topic:330494”]No do my command prompt thing :P.

Apart from this time cd to your Apache2/bin directory and then run httpd.exe…[/quote]
Got this:

(OS 10048)Only one usage of each socket address (protocol/network address/port)
is normally permitted.  : make_sock: could not bind to address 0.0.0.0:80
no listening sockets available, shutting down
Unable to open logs

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

No do my command prompt thing :P.

Apart from this time cd to your Apache2/bin directory and then run httpd.exe…

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“r0ckstar96, post:17, topic:330494”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=426871.msg3135005#msg3135005 date=1266873270]
Is it a batch file? If it is add a ‘pause’ to the end of the batch file.
[/quote]
I put ‘pause’ under the ServerName line and then I got this:

Syntax error on line 171 of C:/Program Files (x86)/Apache Software Foundation/Ap ache2.2/conf/httpd.conf: Invalid command 'pause', perhaps misspelled or defined by a module not included in the server configuration Note the errors or messages above, and press the <ESC> key to exit. 17...[/quote]
Ok cool, it worked. (Don’t listen to Ollie’s command prompt thing :P)

So since Ollie and I were telling you what to do at the same time, I’m guessing that you got confuses and put the wrong code in. Post lines 165-175 again.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:
@r0ckstar96 wrote:

[quote=“ollie123, post:18, topic:330494”]If it’s not a batch file (if you’re running httpd.exe directly) go into Command Prompt, cd to your Apache2 directory and run httpd from the command line, then post the output.

Take the pause out and follow this ^.[/quote]
There was no httpd.exe file. I opened httpd.conf from the command line and it just opened the file.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Web Server help
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

If it’s not a batch file (if you’re running httpd.exe directly) go into Command Prompt, cd to your Apache2 directory and run httpd from the command line, then post the output.

Take the pause out and follow this ^.

Read full topic
